description.narrative: The Joint Security Sector Governance Programme (JSSGP) for Somalia addresses both the federal and member state levels offering a country-wide engagement.

participating-org.narrative: United Nations Multi Partner Trust Fund for Somalia

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

provider-org.narrative: United Nations Multi Partner Trust Fund for Somalia
United Nations Multi Partner Trust Fund for Somalia

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: Indicator 1: #Staff appointed in Ministry of Internal Security Indicator 2: # people trained (M/F) in civilian administration in line with other ministries as per MOIS Training Plan with increase in knowledge Indicator 3: # Office of National Security Staff appointed and paid Indicator 4: # Federal Member States staff appointed in key departments Indicator 5: # of participants in capacity building activities with increase in knowledge to hold the security sector accountable through implementation of its approved Institutional and Capacity Building Plan.

comment.narrative: 1. MOIS ID&CB Plan finalised. 2. Key departments within MOIS staffed with qualified and competent personnel. 3. Staff using SOPs and manuals from trainings 4. Enhanced leadership and management capacity within MOIS 5. Enhanced functionality within the MOIS. 6. At least 2 in second half of 2018. 7. Reforms of the Police Force payroll and personnel management in accordance with the project ToRs implemented. 8. Improved implementation, oversight and coordination of current National Plan. 9. MoD ID&CB Plan finalised. 10. Key departments within MoD staffed with qualified and competent personnel. 11. Effective FGS-FMS security (coordination) meetings 12. Staff using SOPs and manuals from trainings. 13. Enhanced leadership and management capacity within MoD. 14. Enhanced functionality with MoD. 15. Knowledge of mandate of ONS 16. ONS ID&CB Plan finalised. 17. ONS staffed with qualified and competent personnel. 18. Key staff have received training in line with other ministries as per ONS Training Plan. 19. Enhanced analysis capacity for ONS. 20. Enhanced functionality within ONS. 21. ONS facilitates key security events on behalf of FGS 22. Knowledge of mandate of OPM 23. OPM ID&CB Plan finalised. 24. OPM staffed with qualified and competent personnel. 25. Key staff have received training in line with other ministries as per OPM Training Plan. 26. Enhanced functionality within OPM 27. MoS ID&CB Plan for each FMS finalised. 28. Key departments within each FMS MoS staffed with qualified and competent peronnel. 29. key MoS staff trained and using SOPs & manuals from training 30. Enhanced leadership and managment capacity within MoS. 31. Enhanced functionality of FMS MoS. 32. Enhanced analysis capacity for FMSs MoS. 33. FMSs & BRA RSO ID&CB Plan finalised. 34. Knowledge of mandate of RSOs 35. RSOs staffed with qualified and competent personnel. 36. Functional RSOs with qualified personnel. 37. Signed off ID&CB Plan for all Committees. 38. 80% participation in capacity building activities. 39. # Hearings, Committee meetings, and public meetings. 40. Security related law drafted and/or reviewed by Committees. 41. The House of the People (HOTP) Defence Committee gains the knowledge to hold the defence sector accountable through implementation of its approved ID&CB Plan. 42. Enhanced functionality of the HOPT Committee. 43. At least 3. 44. The House of the People (HOTP) Security Committee gains the knowledge to hold the security sector accountable through implementation of its approved ID&CB Plan. 45. At least 3. 46. The Upper House (UH) Security Committee gains the knowledge to hold the defence and security sector accountable through implementation of its approved ID&CB Plan. 47. Enhanced functionality of the UH Committee. 48. At least 3. 49. All FMS Parliamentary Security Committees gain the knowledge to hold the security sector accountable through implementation of its approved ID&CB Plan. 50. Enhanced functionality of the Regional Assembly Committees. 51. Security sector policy that is more inclusive of the impacts on civil society. 52. Functioning civilian oversight mechanisms include women and contribute to law-abiding, accountable and transparent security sector institutions. 53. Enhanced analysis capacity for FGS Parliament

As of June 2020: 1. Interim IDCBP 2020 finalized. 2. 26 staff (F:10; M:16) employed under the JSSGP: 7 advisors, 2 coordinators and 17 consultants. 3. JSSGP Training Concept developed and agreed and 11 training manuals and modules developed. Trainings to be implemented through a ToT process in Q3-Q4 2020. 4. Leadership and Management training package included in the JSSGP Training Concept. Trainings to be implemented through a ToT process in Q3-Q4 2020. 5. Ongoing support including provision of wi-fi, fuel, water, electricity and office consumables. 6. MOIS coordination with FMS MOS is continuous at technical level 7. Ongoing reconciliation of SPF verification data for PL, SWS, GL and HS. Ongoing identification of those who can be offered retirement especially since the Pensions and Gratuity Law has been approved by the Parliament and is awaiting Presidential assent. Verification missions undertaken through the Joint Police Programme 8. Not included in 2020 Annual Workplan, as approved by PSC in December 2019 9. ID&CBP Workshop completed in January 2020. ID&CBP is pending completion. 10. 31 staff (F:6; M:25) currently employed under the JSSGP: 3 advisors, 28 consultants. 11. Operational support included in LoA. Meetings planned for Q3-Q4 2020. 12. ID&CBP Workshop for 26 MoD staff (F:7, M:19) held in Jan 2020 also provided training on deliverables and SSG&SSR. JSSGP Training Concept developed and 11 training manuals and modules developed. Trainings to be implemented through a ToT process in Q3-Q4 2020. 13. Leadership and Management training package included in the JSSGP Training Concept. Trainings to be implemented through a ToT process in Q3-Q4 2020. Initiated the development and drafting of SNA procedures and manuals supporting the SNA reform. MOD Guide drafted and expected to be completed in Q3. 14. Two trainings provided to the MOD by the UNDP Operations team on handling HACT and audit. Successful completion of HACT Assessment with ‘Moderate’ risk rating was achieved. 15. JSSGP Training Concept developed and 11 training manuals and modules developed. Trainings to be implemented through a ToT process in Q3-Q4 2020. 16. ONS ID&CB Plan to be completed Q3 2020. 17. 7 staff (F: 3; M:4) advisors/consultants currently employed in the ONS. 18. JSSGP Training Concept developed and 11 training manuals and modules developed. Trainings to be implemented through a ToT process in Q3-Q4 2020. 19. Monitoring and reporting training to be delivered in Q3-Q4 2020.
20. Two HACT assessments for the Office of Presidents of Hirshabelle and South West were completed in Q2. 21. ONS-RSOs in-person meeting held 20-22 Feb 2020. Ongoing weekly virtual coordination meetings held between the ONS and the RSOs. 22. Completed. 23. OPM ID&CB Plan has been finalized. 24. 19 staff (F:8; M:11) currently employed in OPM: 13 consultants and 5 consultants/advisors 25. Two virtual trainings held: Security sector reform was held on 15-16 June 2020 for 19 staff (F:10, M:9). Gender, Women, Peace and Security on 17 June 2020 for 16 staff (F:10, M:6) 26. Office was temporarily closed due to COVID-19 pandemic and staff moved to a remote working modality. 27. Finalized ID&CB Plans delivered by Puntland MOS and SWS MOSs. ID&CB Plans from Hirshabelle, Galmudug and Jubaland MOSs expected in Q3 2020. 28. 45 advisors/consultants (F:7, M:38) currently employed in the FMS MOSs (11 in Jubaland, 3 in Galmudug, 12 in HirsHabelle, 10 in SWS MOS and 9 in Puntland). 29. JSSGP Training Concept developed and 11 training manuals and modules developed. Trainings to be implemented through a ToT process in Q3-Q4 2020. 30. Leadership and Management training package for all FMS MOSs planned for Q3-Q4 2020 as part of the Training Concept. 31. Ongoing support for Puntland MOS office through improved internet and water supply. Support for other FMS MOS planned for Q3-Q4 2020. 32. Trainings for other FMS MOS to be implemented during Q3-Q4 2020 in accordance with Trainings Concept. 33. Finalized ID&CB plans have been prepared by RSOs of SWS, GM and HS. Draft versions have been prepared by BRA, JL and PL.The RSOs have been implementing their ID&CBPs through supporting Regional Security Council Meetings and operationalizing security services through analyzing and coordinating security actors, providing expert advice, analysis and threat assessments in support of the security agencies in their respective regions. 34. JSSGP Training Concept developed and 11 training manuals and modules developed. Trainings to be implemented through a ToT process in Q3-Q4 2020. 35. 32 staff (F:7; M:25) currently employed in RSOs in PL, SWS, HS, GM, JL and BRA. 36. Packages of office equipment and ICT for each RSO procured from Danish funding were delivered to each of the RSOs in March/April 2020 following the delivery of their ID&CB Plans. During Q2, all RSO staff have worked from home in accordance with government guidelines. 21 RSO personnel have provided support to their respective FMS COVID response task forces. 37. Planned for Q3-Q4 2020 – dicussions ongoing regarding development of LOAs. 38. Parliamentary training sessions included in the JSSGP Training Concept and planned for delivery in Q3-Q4 2020. 39. A ‘Working Together Symposium’ co-facilitated by Defence Committee with NSA, MOD, OPM and SNA is planned for Q3-Q4 2020. Symposium will aim to improve the Legislative-Executive relationship and allow a greater clarity of civil-military relations and institutional roles and responsibilities, as well as the purpose of civilian control and oversight of the military. 40. Planned for Q3-Q4 2020 41. Parliamentary training sessions included in the JSSGP Training Concept and planned for delivery in Q3-Q4 2020. 42. Planned for Q3-Q4 2020 43. HOPT Committee to conduct a parliamentary study tour to Rwanda. The visit delayed due to COVID-19 and anticipated to take place in Q4 2020. 44. Planned for Q3-Q4 2020. 45. HOPT Committee to conduct a parliamentary study tour to Rwanda. The visit delayed due to COVID-19 and anticipated to take place in Q3-Q4 2020. 46. Planned for Q3-Q4 2020. 47. Planned for Q3-Q4 2020. 48. Planned for Q3-Q4 2020. 49. Planned for Q3-Q4 2020. 50. Planned for Q3-Q4 2020. 51. ToR developed for improving CSO engagement in security sector and to be implemented Q3-Q4 2020. 52. ToR developed for improving CSO engagement in security sector and to be implemented Q3-Q4 2020. 53. Not budgeted for 2020.

1.1 At least 70% of MOIS ID&CB Plan Implemented Ministry has expertise to implement the transition period key strategic priorities All staff in the Policy & Legal and Planning & Development receive specialized training Policy & Legal and Planning & Development Departments have a clear a) organogram, b) clear TORs for all staff, c) clear SOPs Enhanced functionality within the MOIS. At least 2 coordination meetings at federal and FMS level (council of security ministries) 1.2 Reforms of the Police Force payroll and personnel management in accordance with the project TORs implemented. 1.3 N/A 1.4 30% of the ID&CB plan implemented Ministry has expertise to implement the ID&CB Plan, NDP, MAF and the STP Effective FGS-FMS security (coordination) meetings Staff receive specialized training Enhanced leadership and management capacity within MoD. JSSGP funded consultants develops a robust asset management, filing and inventory system and guidelines to maintain it in line with the ID&CB 1.5 Knowledge of mandate of ONS
ONS ID&CB Plan finalised. ONS has expertise to implement the transition period key strategic priorities Key staff have received training in line with other ministries as per ONS Training Plan. ONS developed at least 2 SOPs or systems that underpin the TOT training (M&E, Reporting, Asset management, etc) Enhanced functionality within ONS. ONS facilitates key security events on behalf of FGS 1.6 Knowledge of mandate of OPM OPM ID&CB Plan finalized. OPM staffed with qualified and competent personnel. Key staff have received training in line with other ministries as per OPM Training Plan. All ministries have developed at least 2 SOPs or systems that underpin the TOT training (M&E, Reporting, Asset management, etc.) Enhanced functionality within OPM 2.1 MoS ID&CB Plan for each FMS finalized. Ministry has expertise to implement the transition period key strategic priorities. Completion of measurable deliverables in the TORs All JSSGP funded consultants and staff in ministry are exposed to training to increase capacity in the ministry. Enhanced leadership and managment capacity within MOS. Enhanced functionality of FMS MOS. Enhanced analysis capacity for FMSs MoS. 2.2 FMSs & BRA RSO ID&CB Plan finalized. RSOs has expertise to implement the transition period key strategic priorities. Completion of measurable deliverables in the TORs; RSOs develop strategic plans for 2021 RSOs staffed with qualified and competent personnel. Functional RSOs with qualified personnel. 3.1 Signed off ID&CB Plan for all Committees. 1 FMS Legislature is supported to build capacity to increase civilian oversight capacity as a pilot # Hearings, Committee meetings, and public meetings.
Security related law drafted and/or reviewed by Committees.
The House of the People (HOTP) Defence Committee gains the knowledge to hold the defence sector accountable through implementation of its approved ID&CB Plan. Enhanced functionality of the HOPT Committee. At least 3. The House of the People (HOTP) Security Committee gains the knowledge to hold the security sector accountable through implementation of its approved ID&CB Plan. At least 3. The Upper House (UH) Security Committee gains the knowledge to hold the defence and security sector accountable through implementation of its approved ID&CB Plan. Enhanced functionality of the UH Committee. At least 3. All FMS Parliamentary Security Committees gain the knowledge to hold the security sector accountable through implementation of its approved ID&CB Plan. Enhanced functionality of the Regional Assembly Committees. 3.2 Security sector policy that is more inclusive of the impacts on civil society. Functioning civilian oversight mechanisms include women and contribute to law-abiding, accountable and transparent security sector institutions. Enhanced analysis capacity for FGS Parliament

As of programme closure in June 2021:
1.1 MOIS ID&CB Plan completed in 2020. 7 staff (F:1; M:6) currently employed. Meritocracy-based recruitment overseen by UNDP to support a comprehensive training package, Police development, Maritime, STP and electoral security planning. From 22 May to 20 June 2021, 20 participants (M:16, F:4) from the MOIS Policy & Legal and Development & Planning departments received induction training, collective training and individual on the job training with a validation exercise at the end. From 19-20 June 2021, 35 participants (M:5, F:30) from MOIS, OPM, MoWHR, MOD, SNA, and the Police attended a Gender empowerment and mainstreaming workshop. Training package in 2021 included development of polices and guidelines for the ministerial core functions in legal and policy and development and planning. Ongoing support including provision of wi-fi, fuel, water, electricity and office consumables. MOIS coordination with FMS MOS is continuous at technical level through regular and ad-hoc meetings. 1.2 No progress during reporting period 1.3 Removed - no longer funded 1.4 MOD ID&CBP for 2020-2021 completed in August 2020. 12 staff currently funded (F:2; M:10). There was an appraisal where 12 best of the best preforming staff continued during the transition period. JSSGP funded staff attended on behalf of the Ministry multiple coordination meetings including Stabilization meetings and CAS working group meetings. From 19-24 June 2021, 40 participants (M:34, F:6) from MOD received a comprehensive training package covering subjects from Leadership and management, administration, report writing, SSR, Human rights. Following policies developed supported by JSSGP: Gender policy, Human Rights Policy for Defense, Military Police management and control procedures, Defense ACT, Training policy and Administration and Finance management policies for SNA Vehicle hire support for key advisors to perform their duties 1.5 ID&CBP workshops completed in 2019 ONS ID&CB has delivered one year Action Plan that clearly sets out outputs, objectives, activities, and results to be achieved in support of institutional development 5 staff (F: 2; M:3) advisors/consultants currently employed in the ONS.
ONS staff are considered advisors with capacity to implement so their work concentrates on WAM, STP and coordination. The programme provided operational funds and funds for events. ONS led the assessment of the implementation of the STP, supported by JSSGP funded consultants. Reporting was moved back to monthly reporting from every individual in addition to ONS producing quarterly report. Completed 2019. Due to COVID and the political impasse there were limited meetings between January and June 2021. However, several virtual meetings were held between ONS and RSOs and work on WAM and STP coordination continued. 1.6 Completed 2019. OPM ID&CB Plan has been finalized. 16 (F:4 M:12) advisors/consultants currently employed in OPM (including 3 ad hoc brought in due to elections temporarily and 1 person to enhance cyber security) From 08-10 May 2021, 27 participants (M:18, F:7) from the OPM SAU received Security Management, Report Writing and Financial Management training. From 27-29 June 2021, 20 (M:15, F:5) participants from OPM received IT training OPM advisors supported beneficiary ministries by conducting a comprehensive assessment and provided several trainings to on electoral security, strategic planning, M&E, reporting, administration and finance in MOIS Puntland, MOS Galmudug, MOS SWS, MOD and MOIS FGS. Completed 2019. 2.1 The reporting period concentrated on the implementation of the ID&CBPs whereby the majority of the planned training was implemented in 2020 and during the extension period in 2021. 41 advisors/consultants (F:6, M:35) currently employed in the FMS MOSs. Galmudug did not manage to hire staff in 2020 which would explain why the number of posts rose during this period but there were also a couple of additions to support ministerial work on electoral security. From 20-29 March 2021, 20 participants (M:16, F:6) from Puntland MOS&DDR received comprehensive training package. From 22 May to 27 June 2021, 25 participants (M:19, F:6) from SWS MOS received comprehensive training package. From 24 May to 28 May, 39 participants (M:32, F:7) from Puntland MOS&DDR received training on SSR, coordination mechanisms, strategic planning and communications systems from OPM trainers From 31 May-07 June 2021, 25 participants (M:20, F:5) from Hirshabelle MOS received capacity building Training on communications, conflict resolution and asset management. From 31 May-16 June 2021, 41 participants (M:34, F:7) from Galmudug MOS received comprehensive training package. From 15-23 June 2021, 25 participants (M:19, F:6) from Hirshabelle MOS received leadership and management training. From 19-28 June, 25 participants (M:19, F:6) from Puntland MOS&DDR received capacity building training including Security Analysis and Reporting, Community Policing and Human Rights, Financial Management, Office Administration and Management. OPM assessments revealed extensive progress in beneficiary institutions where policies were now in place, HRM systems implemented, documentation improved and basic functions now operational. Ongoing support for Puntland MOS office through improved internet and water supply. The programme reinstated monthly reports from each JSSGP funded statff which improved oversight but the quality of reporting with proper TORs also meant overall improvement in reports. 2.2 Finalized ID&CB plans were prepared by RSOs in 2020. SWS RSO delivered a training on Civilian Oversight in the Security Sector to 30 participants from Police, Justice Actors and Civilian Groups. Regular interactions with ONS and RSOs revealed firm understanding of mandate and added value. RSOs supported ministries, State Houses and Ministries with multiple policy and planning support. 30 staff (F:6; M:24) currently employed in RSOs in PL, SWS, HS, GM, JL and BRA. Completed in 2020 3.1 No activities during reporting period. Limited funds available for parliamentary work during the reporting period but one comprehensive workshop as a part of a pilot was conducted with the Galmudug Parliament. This workshop focused on briefing parliamentary members on current security developments and delving into what role the parliament has in security sector oversight. No activities during the reporting period. No activities during reporting period. The session with the Galmudug State Parliament with 20 participants (F:4, M:16) focused on accountability and the security sector and Parliament’s role in that respect. Completed in 2019. No activities during reporting period. No activities during reporting period. No activities during reporting period. No activities during reporting period. No activities during reporting period. No activities during reporting period. No activities during reporting period. No activities during reporting period. 3.2 No activities during reporting period. Each FMS ministries were awarded with budgets to encourage civil society outreach. Jubaland MOS organized large gathering with Civil Society, but others to much less degree. However, a part of the training conducted at FMS level, the modules also looked at mandates of the ministries and their responsibilities in producing inclusive policies. Not budgeted for 2021.

Target 1: Key departments within Ministry of Internal Security (MOIS) staffed with qualified and competent personnel. Target 2: Staff using SOPs and manuals from trainings Target 3: Office of National Security (ONS) staffed with qualified and competent personnel. Target 4: Key departments within each Federal Member State (FMS) Ministry of Security (MoS) staffed with qualified and competent personnel. Target 5: The House of the People (HOTP) Defence Committee gains the knowledge to hold the defence sector accountable through implementation of its approved Institutional and Capacity Building Plan.

Result 1: 21 staff (F:7; M:14) employed under the JSSGP: 7 advisors, 7 coordinators and 7 consultants Result 2: 253 MOIS staff (F: 55; M: 198) trained in human rights, gender and trauma/stress management Result 3: Total: 20 (F:3: M:17) qualified and competent staff recruited Result 4: 7 regional security advisors/directors recruited and working in the FMS and BRA Result 5: 39 members of parliament targeted with workshops on the drafted Pensions and Gratuities Law
